title: Food Preparation — Banana Slicing
description: The child learns to slice a banana using a child-safe knife. This exercise develops coordination, sequencing, and the independence of preparing one's own snack.
instructions:
1. Wash hands together.
2. Place a banana, cutting board, child-safe knife, and plate on a tray.
3. Demonstrate peeling the banana: pull back each section of peel.
4. Show how to hold the knife safely with the dominant hand and steady the banana with the other.
5. Slice slowly, pressing down and forward.
6. Arrange slices on the plate. Enjoy the snack!

slides.setup_instructions: Wash hands first. Place all materials on a tray. Have a waste bowl ready for the peel.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to prepare our own snack! First, let's peel the banana.' Show how to pull back each strip of peel.
Place the peeled banana on the cutting board. 'Hold the knife in this hand. Keep your other fingers away from the blade.'
Demonstrate one slow slice: press the knife down and forward. 'See how the slice falls? Your turn!'
'Slice the whole banana. Take your time — there is no rush. Put each slice on the plate.'

slides.prompt: Slice the entire banana. Arrange the slices nicely on your plate. How many slices did you make?

slides.text: Enjoy your snack! Then wash the cutting board, knife, and plate. Put the peel in the compost or trash.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child safely peel and slice a banana with minimal assistance?

parent_notes: Food preparation is a cornerstone of Montessori practical life. Using a real knife (even a butter knife) teaches respect for tools and builds confidence. Always supervise closely but avoid hovering. Bananas are ideal for first cutting because they are soft and require minimal force. The child may eat the slices as a natural reward for their work.

title: Sandpaper Letters — Review and Remaining: j, z, q
description: Introduction to three less common sandpaper letters: j, z, and q. These complete the child's exposure to the full alphabet of sandpaper letters.
instructions:
1. Quick review of all previously learned letters (lay out 10, child names each sound).
2. Introduce 'j': trace and say /j/ (as in 'jump'). Three-period lesson.
3. Introduce 'z': trace and say /z/ (buzzing sound). Three-period lesson.
4. Introduce 'q': trace and say /kw/ (always with 'u'). Three-period lesson.
5. Mix new and old letters for recognition practice.
6. I Spy for /j/ and /z/ sounds.
materials_needed: Small objects starting with j and z

items: Objects: jar, jet, zoo animal, zipper
slides.setup_instructions: Place new letters face-down. Have review letters and objects ready.

slides.text: Review: lay out 10 learned letters. Child traces each and says the sound. Celebrate confidence!
Introduce 'j': trace with two fingers. '/j/ — like jump and jar!' Three-period lesson.
Introduce 'z': trace and say /z/ — 'like a buzzing bee! Zzzzz.' Three-period lesson.
Introduce 'q': 'This letter almost always comes with u. Together they say /kw/ — like queen and quilt.'

slides.prompt: I Spy: find objects that start with /j/ and /z/. Then trace all three new letters in the sand tray.

slides.text: 'You are learning ALL the sounds of the alphabet! Soon you will know every single one.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace and produce the sounds /j/, /z/, and /kw/?

parent_notes: These are among the last sandpaper letters introduced because they are less frequent in English. The /q/ sound is unusual because it always pairs with 'u' to make /kw/. Don't worry about mastery of all 26 letters at once — the child will continue to review throughout the year. Celebrate that the child has now been exposed to the complete alphabet!

title: Teen Boards — Introduction (11-13)
description: Introduction to the Montessori teen boards. The child learns how teen numbers are formed by combining a ten and additional units. Starting with 11, 12, and 13.
instructions:
1. Present the teen board (a board with printed '10' slots where a digit card slides over the 0).
2. Place the 10 bead bar next to the board.
3. Slide the '1' card over the zero: 'Now it says 11.' Place one unit bead next to the ten bar.
4. Count: 'Ten and one more is eleven.'
5. Repeat with 12 and 13.
6. Three-period lesson: 'This is twelve. Show me thirteen. What number is this?'

slides.setup_instructions: Place the teen board on a mat. Have ten bars and unit beads in a tray nearby.

slides.text: 'You know numbers 1 to 10. Now we are going to learn numbers that come AFTER ten! These are called teen numbers.'
Point to the board showing '10.' 'This says ten. Watch what happens when I slide this card.' Slide '1' over the 0. 'Now it says ELEVEN — 11!'
Place a ten bar and one unit bead beside it. 'See? Ten and one more is eleven.' Count the beads: 'Ten... eleven!'
Slide '2' over: 'TWELVE — ten and two more!' Place ten bar and 2 unit beads. Then do thirteen.

slides.prompt: Build 11, 12, and 13 with the beads. Then play: I say a number, you build it on the board and with beads!

slides.text: 'Eleven, twelve, thirteen — each one is ten plus some more! We will learn more teen numbers this week.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child form and name 11, 12, and 13 using the teen board and beads?

parent_notes: The teen board is a brilliant Montessori material that makes the confusing teen numbers concrete. Children can SEE that 13 is a ten and three ones. The irregular names (eleven, twelve) are harder than the regular pattern (thirteen = three-teen). Be patient with these. Using the bead bars alongside the board connects quantity to symbol.

title: Constructive Triangles — First Box Review and Discoveries
description: Revisiting the blue constructive triangles to discover all possible shapes that can be made, recording findings in a geometry journal.
instructions:
1. Open the blue constructive triangles box.
2. Take out two right-angled triangles of equal size.
3. Match the black lines together. 'What shape did we make?' (A rectangle!)
4. Continue with other pairs: two form a square, two form a larger triangle.
5. Let the child explore different combinations.
6. Name the resulting shapes.

slides.heading: Constructive Triangles
slides.subheading: Constructive Triangles — First Box Review and Discoveries

slides.setup_instructions: Place all triangles from the box on the mat, scattered gently.

slides.text: 'These are all triangles. But did you know we can combine triangles to make OTHER shapes? Let's discover!'
Take two matching right-angled triangles. 'See the black lines? When we put the black lines together...' Join them. 'A rectangle!'
Try another pair: 'These two make a square!' And another: 'These make a bigger triangle!'
'Triangles are building blocks for many shapes. Every shape can be made from triangles!'

slides.prompt: Match all the pairs by their black lines. How many different shapes can you make? Name each one!

slides.text: Return all triangles to the box. 'Triangles are the building blocks of geometry!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child combine triangles to form at least 3 different shapes?

parent_notes: The constructive triangles reveal one of geometry's great secrets: any polygon can be divided into triangles. This is deep mathematical thinking presented as a simple puzzle! The black lines guide the child to correct pairings. Once mastered with lines, future work removes the lines and the child must figure out combinations independently. If you don't have official materials, cut triangles from colored cardboard.

title: Read-Aloud: The Tiny Seed by Eric Carle
description: Reading 'The Tiny Seed' by Eric Carle, exploring the life cycle of a plant through the seasons. This connects to the science curriculum on plant life cycles.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'What do you see? What might this story be about?'
2. Read slowly, pointing out the collage illustrations.
3. Pause at each season: 'What season is it now in the story?'
4. Discuss the challenges the seeds face: too hot, too cold, eaten by birds.
5. 'What happened to the tiny seed? It survived and grew into a beautiful flower!'
6. Connect to real life: 'What seeds have you planted?'
materials_needed: The Tiny Seed by Eric Carle
Optional: real seeds to hold during the story

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: The Tiny Seed by Eric Carle

slides.setup_instructions: Sit together comfortably. If you have seeds, let the child hold one during the story.

slides.text: Show the cover: 'This is called The Tiny Seed. What do you think will happen to this little seed?'
Read slowly. At each season, pause: 'Now it's autumn. What's happening to the seeds?'
Discuss the dangers: 'Oh no! One seed flew too high near the sun. One landed on ice. What happened to them?'

slides.prompt: After reading: 'What does a seed need to grow? Can you put the seasons in order: fall, winter, spring, summer?'

slides.text: 'The tiny seed grew into a giant flower! Even small things can become something big.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the basic sequence of the seed's journey through the seasons?

parent_notes: This book beautifully connects to the science curriculum on plant life cycles. Eric Carle's collage art style is wonderful for children. The story teaches perseverance — the tiny seed survives when bigger seeds do not. Consider planting a real seed after reading this book so the child can observe the life cycle firsthand.

title: Binomial Cube — Introduction
description: Introduction to the binomial cube as a sensorial puzzle. The child assembles the cube by matching colors and shapes, building spatial reasoning and preparing for future algebra.
instructions:
1. Open the binomial cube box. Remove the lid and show the completed cube.
2. Carefully lift the cube out and place on the mat.
3. Gently separate the top layer. Name the colors: 'Red cube, red-and-black prism, red-and-blue prism.'
4. Rebuild the top layer following the painted pattern on the box lid.
5. Separate and rebuild the bottom layer.
6. The child practices rebuilding one layer at a time.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the box on a mat. The painted pattern on the lid and sides serves as the control of error.

slides.text: 'This is the binomial cube. It's like a beautiful 3D puzzle! Let's see what's inside.' Open the box.
Lift out the cube carefully. Point to the colors: 'Red cube, blue cube, and prisms of red-black and blue-black.'
Separate ONLY the top layer. 'The lid shows us the pattern. Let's match the colors and rebuild this layer.'
Place each piece following the painted guide on the box lid. 'Red cube in the corner, then the matching prisms beside it.'

slides.prompt: Take apart the top layer and rebuild it. Then try the bottom layer. Can you put the whole cube back together?

slides.text: Close the box with the completed cube inside. 'You solved the binomial cube!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child rebuild at least one layer of the binomial cube using the painted guide?

parent_notes: The binomial cube is a sensorial material that indirectly represents the algebraic formula (a+b) cubed. At this age, the child works with it purely as a 3D puzzle. The painted pattern on the box serves as the control of error — the child can self-correct. Never explain the algebra; let the child simply enjoy the puzzle. Mastery comes through repetition over weeks and months.

title: Moveable Alphabet — Introduction
description: Introduction to the Montessori moveable alphabet. The child learns how to find letters in the compartments and begins building simple three-letter words.
instructions:
1. Present the moveable alphabet box. Show the organization: each letter has its own compartment.
2. 'These letters are for BUILDING words. Let's build some!'
3. Say the word 'cat' slowly: /k/-/a/-/t/. 'What's the first sound?'
4. Child finds 'c' in the box. Then 'a'. Then 't'. Arrange on the mat: cat.
5. Build 3-4 more CVC words: mat, sat, pin, dog.
6. Child reads each word back after building.

items: Optional: miniature objects to match words
slides.setup_instructions: Place the moveable alphabet on a table. Lay a mat below for word building.

slides.text: 'This is the moveable alphabet! Every letter has its own home in the box. Let's explore it.'
Show the child how to find letters: 'Here are all the a's. Here are all the t's. We can use them to build words!'
Say 'cat' slowly: /k/-/a/-/t/. 'What sound do you hear first?' Child finds 'c.' 'Next sound?' Find 'a.' 'Last sound?' Find 't.'
Arrange on mat left to right: c-a-t. 'You built CAT! Can you read it back to me?'

slides.prompt: Build these words: mat, sat, pin, dog. Sound each word out first, then find the letters. Read each word when done!

slides.text: Return all letters to their compartments. 'You are a word builder! You can write with the moveable alphabet!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sound out and build at least 3 CVC words with the moveable alphabet?

parent_notes: The moveable alphabet is one of the most important Montessori language materials. It allows the child to 'write' before their hand is ready for pencil writing. The key skill is segmenting — breaking a spoken word into its individual sounds. Don't worry about perfect spelling at this stage; phonetic attempts are celebrated. The child may spell 'cat' as 'kat' — this shows strong phonetic thinking!

title: Teen Boards — 14, 15, 16
description: Continuing with the teen boards: learning to form and name 14, 15, and 16 with the board and golden beads.
instructions:
1. Review 11, 12, 13 with the teen board.
2. Build 14: slide '4' card, place ten bar and 4 unit beads. 'Fourteen — ten and four!'
3. Build 15: slide '5' card, place beads. 'Fifteen — ten and five!'
4. Build 16: slide '6' card, place beads. 'Sixteen — ten and six!'
5. Three-period lesson for all six teen numbers.
6. Random practice: 'Build fifteen!' 'What number is this?'

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the teen board on a mat. Have beads ready in a tray.

slides.text: Review: 'Let's remember our teen numbers!' Build 11, 12, 13 quickly with the board and beads.
Build 14: slide the '4' over the zero. Place a ten bar and 4 unit beads. 'Ten and four — FOURTEEN!'
Build 15: 'Ten and five — FIFTEEN!' Build 16: 'Ten and six — SIXTEEN!'
Notice the pattern: 'Four-teen has four. Five-teen... we say fifteen. Six-teen has six.'

slides.prompt: I say a number, you build it! 'Build fourteen!' 'Now thirteen!' Mix them up for a challenge.

slides.text: 'Six teen numbers so far — 11 through 16! You are counting past ten!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child form and name numbers 11-16?

parent_notes: Notice the naming pattern: 13 (three-teen), 14 (four-teen), 15 (fif-teen), 16 (six-teen). The names become more regular after the tricky 11 and 12. Point out this pattern to help the child predict future teen names. The concrete beads make it clear that each teen number is 'ten and some more.'

title: Parts of a Plant — Root, Stem, Leaf, Flower
description: Introduction to the four main parts of a plant. The child examines a real plant and learns the function of each part using Montessori nomenclature cards.
instructions:
1. Place a whole plant (with roots visible) on the work mat.
2. Point to each part: 'This is the root. It drinks water from the soil.'
3. 'This is the stem. It holds the plant up and carries water to the leaves.'
4. 'These are the leaves. They make food from sunlight.'
5. 'This is the flower. It makes seeds for new plants.'
6. Match nomenclature cards to the real plant parts.
materials_needed: A whole plant with visible roots (pulled from soil or a seedling in water)

items: A real plant with visible roots
slides.setup_instructions: Gently pull a small plant from soil or use a seedling grown in water so roots are visible. Lay it on the mat.

slides.text: 'Plants have parts, just like our body has parts. Let's learn the four main parts of a plant!'
Touch the roots: 'These are the ROOTS. They grow under the ground and drink water for the plant.' Look with the magnifying glass.
Touch the stem: 'This is the STEM. It's like the plant's backbone — it holds everything up and carries water from the roots to the leaves.'
Touch a leaf: 'These are the LEAVES. They make food for the plant using sunlight!' Touch the flower if present: 'The FLOWER makes seeds.'

slides.prompt: Match the nomenclature cards to the real plant parts. Then draw and label your own plant with all four parts!

slides.text: 'Root, stem, leaf, flower — every plant has these parts working together!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and point to all four parts of a plant?

parent_notes: Using a real plant makes this lesson concrete and memorable. Bean sprouts or herbs from the garden work well because the roots are easy to see. Nomenclature cards are a Montessori staple: each card has a picture with one part highlighted and its label. You can make these at home by printing and labeling simple plant diagrams. This lesson connects beautifully to The Tiny Seed read-aloud.

title: Watercolor Techniques — Wet on Wet
description: Introduction to watercolor painting using the wet-on-wet technique. The child learns to prepare the paper, wet it with a sponge, and apply color.
instructions:
1. Show the watercolor supplies: paints, brush, water cup, paper, sponge.
2. Demonstrate wetting the paper evenly with the damp sponge.
3. Dip the brush in water, then into paint. Touch the wet paper — 'Watch the color spread!'
4. Show how to rinse the brush between colors.
5. Let the child paint freely on wet paper.
6. Observe how colors blend and flow together.

slides.setup_instructions: Cover the table. Put on a smock. Fill the water cup. Lay out paints and paper.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to paint with watercolors! First, we make our paper WET.' Dampen the sponge and stroke it across the paper.
'Now dip the brush in water, then into the paint. Touch the wet paper gently and watch!' The color flows and spreads.
'To change colors, rinse your brush in the water cup. Dip into the new color. See how they blend on the wet paper!'

slides.prompt: Paint freely on your wet paper. Try two or three colors. What happens where the colors meet?

slides.text: Let the painting dry flat. Rinse the brush and clean up. 'Watercolors are magical — the colors flow like rivers!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child wet paper, apply paint, and rinse the brush between colors?

parent_notes: Wet-on-wet watercolor is a Waldorf and Montessori staple. It produces beautiful, flowing results even for beginners, building confidence. The key skills are: wetting paper evenly, using enough water on the brush, and rinsing between colors. Accept that the paper will buckle — use thicker paper or watercolor paper for better results. Display the painting proudly when dry.

title: Sewing — Running Stitch Practice on Burlap
description: Practicing the running stitch on burlap with increasing independence, focusing on even stitch length and tension.
instructions:
1. Prepare a burlap square with a simple straight-line pattern drawn or traced.
2. Thread the needle with yarn. Tie a large knot at the end.
3. Demonstrate: push the needle up from the back, pull through, push down a short distance away, pull through.
4. 'Up, down, up, down — this is called a running stitch.'
5. Let the child practice along the drawn line.
6. Tie off the end when finished.

slides.heading: Sewing
slides.subheading: Sewing — Running Stitch Practice on Burlap

slides.setup_instructions: Draw a straight line on the burlap. Thread the needle and tie a knot. Optional: secure burlap in an embroidery hoop.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to learn to sew! Sewing uses a needle and thread to connect fabric.'
Show the threaded needle. 'Watch: I push the needle UP through the fabric from behind.' Pull the yarn through.
'Now I push the needle DOWN through the fabric a little bit forward.' Pull through. 'Up, down, up, down.'
'This is called a RUNNING STITCH. It looks like dashes on top and dashes on the bottom.'

slides.prompt: Sew along the line using the running stitch. Take your time — up, down, up, down. Follow the line!

slides.text: When you reach the end, help tie a knot. 'You made your first stitches! You are a sewer!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently push the needle up and down to create a running stitch?

parent_notes: Sewing is an excellent Montessori practical life work that develops concentration, hand-eye coordination, and bilateral coordination. Burlap is ideal for beginners because it has large, visible holes. Blunt tapestry needles are safe for children. Keep the yarn relatively short (18 inches) to prevent tangling. This work can be placed on the shelf for independent practice once demonstrated.

title: Moveable Alphabet — CVC Word Lists
description: Building CVC (consonant-vowel-consonant) words with the moveable alphabet, organized by word families: -at, -an, -ig.
instructions:
1. Review the moveable alphabet and how to find letters.
2. 'Today we are going to build word families! Words that rhyme.'
3. Build 'cat.' Change the 'c' to 'b' — 'bat!' Change to 'h' — 'hat!' Change to 's' — 'sat!'
4. Start -an family: can, man, ran, van, fan.
5. Start -ig family: big, dig, pig, wig, fig.
6. Child reads each word as it is built.

slides.setup_instructions: Clear a large mat. Open the moveable alphabet where the child can reach all compartments.

slides.text: 'Word families are groups of words that sound the same at the end. They RHYME!' Build 'cat' on the mat.
'If I change the first letter to b...' swap c for b, 'now it says BAT! What if I use h?' Hat!
Continue the -at family: sat, mat, rat, pat, fat. 'How many -at words can we make?'
New family! Build 'can.' Change the first letter: man, ran, van, fan, pan. Then try -ig: big, dig, pig, wig.

slides.prompt: Pick a word family and build as many words as you can! Change only the first letter each time.

slides.text: 'You built so many words today! Word families help us read — if you know 'cat,' you can read 'bat' and 'hat!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build and read 3+ words in at least two word families?

parent_notes: Word families (also called phonograms or rimes) are powerful for reading because they show the child that words follow patterns. Once the child can read 'cat,' they can read bat, hat, mat, sat, rat, fat, and pat — that's 7 words from knowing the pattern! Keep it playful. If the child builds a nonsense word like 'zat,' laugh together and say it's a silly word.

title: Teen Boards — 17, 18, 19
description: Completing the teen board sequence with 17, 18, and 19. The child now knows all teen numbers from 11 to 19.
instructions:
1. Review 11-16 quickly.
2. Build 17: slide '7' card, place ten bar and 7 unit beads. 'Seventeen — ten and seven!'
3. Build 18: 'Eighteen — ten and eight!'
4. Build 19: 'Nineteen — ten and nine!'
5. Full sequence: build all nine teen numbers in order.
6. Random practice: 'Build seventeen!' 'What number is this?'

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the teen board. Have plenty of unit beads available (up to 9).

slides.text: Quick review: build 11 through 16 with the child. Celebrate how much they know!
Build 17: slide the '7' over. 'Seven-teen! Ten and seven.' Place a ten bar and 7 unit beads.
Build 18: 'Eight-teen! Ten and eight.' Build 19: 'Nine-teen! Ten and nine.' 'What comes after 19? TWENTY!'
'Let's count all the teen numbers: 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19!'

slides.prompt: Build all teen numbers in order. Then I'll call out random numbers — build them as fast as you can!

slides.text: 'You know ALL the teen numbers! From 11 to 19. Every single one!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build and name any teen number from 11-19?

parent_notes: Completing the teen boards is a milestone. The child now understands that each teen number is composed of ten plus additional units. This understanding is crucial for place value. After 19, the next step will be the ten boards (10, 20, 30...). Play teen number games throughout the day: 'You ate 14 grapes!' 'There are 17 steps!'

title: Puzzle Map — World Continents
description: Introduction to the Montessori world puzzle map. The child removes and replaces continent pieces, reinforcing continent names, shapes, and locations.
instructions:
1. Present the world puzzle map.
2. 'This is a map of our whole world! Let's find each continent.'
3. Remove North America first. Name it and describe its shape.
4. Replace it. Remove South America. Continue with each continent.
5. Remove all continents. Can the child replace them all?
6. Name the oceans between the continents.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the puzzle map on a table or large mat. Ensure the child can reach all pieces.

slides.text: 'This is a puzzle map of the world. Each colored piece is a continent. Let's name them as we take them out.'
Remove North America (orange): 'This is North America — where we live! Look at its shape.' Replace it.
Continue with each continent, removing and replacing one at a time. Name the Montessori color for each.
Point to the blue areas: 'The blue is OCEAN — water. The Pacific Ocean is the biggest!'

slides.prompt: Remove ALL the continents. Now put them all back! Can you name each one as you place it?

slides.text: 'You can build the whole world with this map! Seven continents and five oceans.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and correctly place at least 5 of the 7 continents?

parent_notes: Puzzle maps are one of the most popular Montessori materials. The knob on each piece allows easy removal and replacement. The physical act of picking up a continent piece helps the child feel its shape and size. If you don't have a Montessori puzzle map, use a foam world puzzle or print continent shapes to cut out. The Montessori colors are consistent: North America=orange, South America=pink, Europe=red, Asia=yellow, Africa=green, Oceania=brown, Antarctica=white.

title: Read-Aloud: The Reason for a Flower by Ruth Heller
description: Reading 'The Reason for a Flower' by Ruth Heller, a beautifully illustrated nonfiction book about plant parts, pollination, and how flowers become fruits and seeds.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'What do you think the reason for a flower is?'
2. Read aloud, pausing at Ruth Heller's gorgeous illustrations.
3. Point out the plant parts as they are introduced: petals, stamens, pistils.
4. Discuss pollination: 'How do bees help flowers?'
5. Connect to seeds and fruits: 'So a flower's reason is to make seeds!'
6. If available, examine a real flower and find the parts.
materials_needed: The Reason for a Flower by Ruth Heller
Optional: a real flower to dissect

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: The Reason for a Flower by Ruth Heller

items: The Reason for a Flower book
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. If you have a flower, set it aside for after reading.

slides.text: Cover: 'What do you think the reason for a flower is? Let's find out!'
Read slowly — Ruth Heller's rhyming text and detailed illustrations deserve time. Point out plant parts as they appear.
Discuss: 'What is the flower's job? How do bees help? What happens after the flower is pollinated?'

slides.prompt: If you have a real flower, gently take it apart. Can you find the petals, the stem, the stamens? Draw and label a flower.

slides.text: 'Flowers are beautiful, but they also have an important job — making seeds so new plants can grow!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain that flowers help make seeds?

parent_notes: Ruth Heller's nonfiction picture books are stunning and scientifically accurate. This book connects beautifully to botany studies in the Montessori curriculum. The rhyming text makes scientific concepts accessible. Consider pairing with a real flower dissection for hands-on learning.

title: Food Preparation — Spreading Variety (Cream Cheese and Hummus)
description: Practicing spreading skills with different textures: cream cheese, hummus, and other spreads on crackers and bread.
instructions:
1. Wash hands together.
2. Arrange materials on a tray: crackers, small bowl of spread, butter knife, plate.
3. Demonstrate: hold the cracker in one hand, scoop a small amount of spread with the knife.
4. Spread from the center outward. 'Use gentle pressure — the cracker can break!'
5. Place the prepared cracker on the plate.
6. Child prepares their own crackers for snack.
materials_needed: Soft spread (cream cheese, hummus, or butter)

slides.heading: Food Preparation
slides.subheading: Food Preparation — Spreading Variety (Cream Cheese and Hummus)

slides.setup_instructions: Wash hands. Place a small amount of spread in the bowl. Arrange everything on a tray.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to prepare crackers with a spread. First, hold the cracker flat in your hand.'
'Scoop a SMALL amount of spread with the knife. Just a little — you can always add more.'
'Spread from the middle out to the edges. Be gentle — crackers can break if you press too hard!'
Show the finished cracker. 'Beautiful! Now you try. Prepare as many crackers as you would like for your snack.'

slides.prompt: Prepare 4-6 crackers with spread. Practice using gentle pressure. Arrange them nicely on your plate.

slides.text: Enjoy your snack! Then wash the knife, bowl, and plate. Wipe the tray clean.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child spread without breaking the cracker and clean up independently?

parent_notes: Spreading is a wonderful fine motor exercise that also produces a real snack — natural motivation! Choose sturdy crackers that resist breaking. Cream cheese and hummus are both easy spreads for beginners. The challenge of using gentle pressure teaches the child to modulate force. This can become a regular snack-time independence activity.

title: CVC Words — Object to Word Matching
description: The child matches small objects to written CVC words, building the connection between written and spoken language.
instructions:
1. Place 6 small objects on a mat: cat (toy), hat, cup, pen, dog, mop.
2. Write or print 6 CVC word cards: cat, hat, cup, pen, dog, mop.
3. Place the word cards face up.
4. Point to 'cat': sound it out together: /k/-/a/-/t/. 'Which object is cat?'
5. Child matches all 6 objects to word cards.
6. Extension: child reads the words independently first, then finds the object.

items: 6 miniature objects: cat, hat, cup, pen, dog, mop
slides.setup_instructions: Arrange objects in a row. Place word cards face up below them in scrambled order.

slides.text: 'Here are some objects and some words. Let's read the words and find the matching objects!'
Point to the first word card: 'Let's sound it out: /k/-/a/-/t/. Cat! Which object is a cat?' Child places object on the card.
Continue with each word. Let the child try sounding out independently before helping.
Extension: scramble everything. Child reads each word card on their own and places the matching object.

slides.prompt: Match all 6 objects to their words. Then try: I'll say a word, you find BOTH the card and the object!

slides.text: 'You are READING words and matching them to real things! That is what reading is all about!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read and match at least 4 out of 6 CVC words?

parent_notes: Object-to-word matching is a critical Montessori reading activity. It connects the abstract (written word) to the concrete (real object). Use objects the child can name easily. If you don't have miniatures, use photos or real items from around the house. The child sounding out the word independently — even haltingly — is a huge milestone. Celebrate every attempt!

title: Ten Boards — Introduction (10-50)
description: Introduction to the Montessori ten boards (tens boards). The child learns the names of the tens: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, and builds them with bead bars.
instructions:
1. Present the ten board showing '10' repeated.
2. Point to the first 10: 'Ten.' Slide '2' to make 20: 'Twenty — two tens!'
3. Place 2 ten bead bars beside it.
4. Continue: 30 (three tens), 40 (four tens), 50 (five tens).
5. Three-period lesson: 'This is thirty. Show me fifty. What is this?'
6. Count the bead bars for each number.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the ten board on the mat. Have 5 ten bars ready in a tray.

slides.text: 'You know teen numbers — now let's learn the BIG tens! Ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty.'
Point to 10 on the board. 'This is ten — one ten.' Place one ten bar beside it.
Make 20: 'Twenty means TWO tens!' Place 2 ten bars. Make 30: 'THREE tens — thirty!'
Continue to 40 and 50. Count the ten bars each time: 'One ten, two tens, three tens — thirty!'

slides.prompt: Build each number with ten bars. Then play: 'Show me forty!' 'How many tens make fifty?'

slides.text: '10, 20, 30, 40, 50 — each one is made of groups of TEN! Next time we'll go all the way to 100!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and build 10-50 using ten bars?

parent_notes: The ten board helps children understand our base-10 number system. Each ten has a name (twenty, thirty, etc.) and can be seen as a group of ten-bars. The concrete bead bars make this visible and tangible. Twenty is literally two ten-bars side by side. This understanding of place value is essential for all future math.

title: Flags of the World — Introduction
description: Introduction to world flags. The child learns that each country has its own flag and explores the flags of 4-5 countries, starting with their own.
instructions:
1. Show your country's flag. 'This is the flag of our country. Each country has its own special flag.'
2. Discuss colors and symbols: 'What colors do you see? What shapes?'
3. Introduce 3-4 more flags: Canada, Mexico, Japan, Brazil.
4. Match flags to continents on the puzzle map.
5. 'Flags tell us about a country's story.'
6. Child draws their favorite flag.
materials_needed: Small flags or flag cards (5-6 countries)
Paper and crayons for flag drawing

items: 5-6 small flags or printed flag cards
slides.setup_instructions: Select flags with distinctive, simple designs. Have the puzzle map nearby.

slides.text: Show your country's flag: 'This is OUR flag! It has [describe colors and symbols]. Every country in the world has its own flag.'
Show Japan's flag: 'A white flag with a red circle — the sun!' Place it on Asia on the map.
Show Brazil's flag: 'Green, yellow, blue, and white — with stars!' Place it on South America.
Continue with 2-3 more flags. Match each to its continent on the puzzle map.

slides.prompt: Choose your favorite flag and draw it! Try to match the colors and shapes. Which flag do you like best?

slides.text: 'Flags are beautiful and each one tells a story about its country. We will learn more flags this year!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify at least 3 flags and match them to their continent?

parent_notes: Children are often fascinated by flags. Start with simple, distinctive flags (Japan's circle, Canada's maple leaf) before more complex designs. Flag work connects geography, culture, art, and fine motor skills (drawing flags). You can make a flag book or flag display. Miniature flags on toothpicks stuck in clay are wonderful for matching to the puzzle map.

title: Watercolor Techniques — Color Mixing on Paper
description: Exploring color mixing with watercolors. The child paints two colors side by side and watches them blend to create a new color.
instructions:
1. Set up watercolor supplies.
2. Review wet-on-wet technique from earlier this week.
3. 'Let's discover what happens when colors meet!' Paint a stripe of yellow, then a stripe of blue touching it.
4. Watch where they meet: 'Green! Yellow and blue make green!'
5. Try red + yellow = orange. Red + blue = purple.
6. Free painting using all the new colors.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up painting area. Wet the paper lightly with the sponge.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to make NEW colors! Watch this.' Paint yellow on one side of the wet paper.
Paint blue right next to the yellow. 'Look where they meet — what color do you see?' GREEN!
On a new paper: red + yellow = orange! Red + blue = purple! 'We made THREE new colors from THREE primary colors!'

slides.prompt: Create a painting using both primary and mixed colors. How many different colors can you make?

slides.text: 'Red, yellow, and blue are PRIMARY colors. When we mix them, we make SECONDARY colors: green, orange, purple!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create at least 2 secondary colors by mixing primaries?

parent_notes: Color mixing with watercolors is more magical than with other media because the colors blend naturally on wet paper. This connects to the sensorial color tablet work. Use the correct vocabulary: primary colors (red, yellow, blue) and secondary colors (green, orange, purple). Keep extra paper handy — children often want to experiment repeatedly!

title: Sound Cylinders — Matching and Memory Game
description: Using the sound cylinders in a matching game, shaking and listening carefully to pair identical sounds from the two boxes, then playing a memory-style game.
instructions:
1. Present the two boxes of sound cylinders (one with red lids, one with blue lids).
2. Shake one red cylinder. Shake each blue cylinder until a match is found.
3. 'Listen carefully — do these sound the same?' Place matches together.
4. Continue until all pairs are matched.
5. Grade from softest to loudest.
6. Three-period lesson: 'This is loud. This is soft. Which is louder?'

slides.heading: Sound Cylinders
slides.subheading: Sound Cylinders — Matching and Memory Game

items: Sound cylinders — red set and blue set (6 each)
slides.setup_instructions: Place red cylinders on one side, blue on the other. Ensure a quiet room for listening.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to use our EARS! These cylinders each make a different sound. Let's find the matches.'
Shake one red cylinder near your ear. 'Listen to this sound.' Now shake each blue cylinder. 'Does THIS one match?'
When a match is found: 'Yes! These sound the same!' Place them together in the center.
Continue matching all 6 pairs. 'Your ears are like scientists — listening and comparing!'

slides.prompt: Match all the pairs. Then put them in order from softest to loudest. Can you hear the differences?

slides.text: 'You matched all the sounds! Your ears can hear very small differences.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly match at least 4 of the 6 sound pairs?

parent_notes: Sound cylinders train auditory discrimination, which supports phonemic awareness and music appreciation. The room must be quiet for this work. If you don't have Montessori sound cylinders, make your own: fill opaque containers (film canisters, small bottles) in matching pairs with rice, beans, sand, bells, beads, and salt. The child should not be able to see inside. This is a wonderful independent activity once demonstrated.

title: CVC Word Reading — Short Sentences
description: The child begins reading simple sentences made of CVC words: 'The cat sat.' Building from word reading to sentence reading.
instructions:
1. Review reading 5-6 CVC words.
2. Introduce sight words: 'the', 'a', 'is', 'on'. 'Some words we just learn by sight.'
3. Build a sentence with the moveable alphabet or word cards: 'The cat sat.'
4. Child reads the sentence. Act it out!
5. Build more: 'A dog ran.' 'The pig is big.'
6. Child illustrates their favorite sentence.
materials_needed: Moveable alphabet or printed word cards
Sight word cards (the, a, is, on)

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare word cards for common CVC words and sight words. Lay out on a mat.

slides.text: 'You can read words! Now let's put words together to make SENTENCES — sentences tell us something.'
Show sight word cards: 'the' and 'a.' 'These little words help sentences work. We learn them by looking at them many times.'
Build: 'The cat sat.' Point to each word. Child reads each word, then the whole sentence. 'The cat sat! Can you sit like a cat?'
Build more sentences: 'A dog ran.' 'The pig is big.' 'A man sat on a mat.'

slides.prompt: Read each sentence. Pick your favorite and draw a picture of it! Can you build your OWN sentence?

slides.text: 'You are reading SENTENCES! Words make sentences, and sentences tell stories!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read at least 2 simple CVC sentences?

parent_notes: Moving from single words to sentences is a thrilling milestone. Sight words (the, a, is, on) don't follow simple phonetic rules, so we teach them as whole words. Keep sentences very short at first (3-4 words). Acting out sentences makes them fun and meaningful. If the child can build their own sentence, even a simple one like 'a cat sat,' they are truly writing!

title: Ten Boards — Extension to 100
description: Extending the ten board work through 60, 70, 80, 90, and 100. The child counts by tens to 100 using bead bars.
instructions:
1. Review 10-50 from the previous lesson.
2. Continue: 60 (six tens), 70 (seven tens), 80 (eight tens), 90 (nine tens).
3. Place ten bars in rows for each: 'Count with me: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90!'
4. Introduce 100: 'Ten tens make ONE HUNDRED!' Show the golden bead hundred square.
5. Count by tens to 100.
6. Celebrate reaching 100!

slides.setup_instructions: You will need 10 ten bars. Have the hundred square ready for the big reveal.

slides.text: Quick review: build 10, 20, 30, 40, 50 on the board with bead bars.
Continue: 60 (six tens), 70 (seven tens), 80 (eight tens), 90 (nine tens). Count the bars each time.
'Now let's count by tens: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90... and what comes next?'
'ONE HUNDRED! 100! Ten groups of ten makes 100!' Show the hundred square. 'Feel how many beads!'

slides.prompt: Count by tens to 100. Line up all ten bars — then compare them to the hundred square. They are the same!

slides.mastery_check: Can the child count by tens to 100?

parent_notes: Counting to 100 by tens is a major milestone. The hundred square makes this concrete — the child can hold and feel 100. Point out that the ten bars lined up equal the hundred square. This is the foundation of the golden bead decimal system work. Practice skip counting by tens during daily life: while climbing stairs, doing jumping jacks, or driving past houses.

title: Life Cycle of a Bean Plant
description: Planting a bean seed and learning about the life cycle of a plant: seed, sprout, seedling, mature plant, flower, fruit/seed.
instructions:
1. Show a dry bean seed. 'This tiny seed will become a big plant!'
2. Plant the seed in a clear cup with damp paper towels (so roots are visible).
3. Show the life cycle cards: seed → sprout → seedling → plant → flower → fruit → seed.
4. 'A plant starts as a seed, grows, makes flowers, then makes NEW seeds!'
5. Place the cup in a sunny spot.
6. Create a life cycle drawing or chart.

slides.setup_instructions: Fold damp paper towels inside the clear cup. Tuck seeds between the towel and the cup wall.

slides.text: 'This is a bean seed. Inside this tiny seed is everything needed to grow a whole plant!'
Plant the seed: damp paper towel in the cup, seed between the towel and cup wall. 'Now we can watch through the cup!'
Show the life cycle: 'Seed → sprout → seedling → plant → flower → fruit (with new seeds!) → and the cycle starts again!'
'A life cycle is a circle — it goes around and around. The plant makes seeds that become NEW plants.'

slides.prompt: Draw the life cycle of a bean plant. Put the stages in a circle: seed, sprout, seedling, plant, flower, fruit.

slides.text: 'We'll check our seed every day! How many days until it sprouts?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 4 stages of the plant life cycle?

parent_notes: Planting a bean seed in a clear cup is a classic Montessori science activity. Using a clear cup allows the child to observe root growth — something normally hidden underground. Beans sprout quickly (3-5 days), maintaining the child's interest. Check the seed daily and keep the paper towel damp. This connects to The Tiny Seed read-aloud and parts of a plant lesson.

title: Printmaking — Flower and Nature Prints
description: Creating prints using flowers, seed pods, and other nature items, exploring how different textures create unique patterns.
instructions:
1. Collect several leaves with prominent veins.
2. Demonstrate: paint one side of a leaf (vein side up) with tempera paint.
3. Press the painted leaf onto paper, press firmly, then lift carefully.
4. 'Look — a print! You can see all the leaf's details!'
5. Try different leaves and colors.
6. Create a leaf print collage or pattern.

slides.setup_instructions: Cover the table. Put on a smock. Lay out leaves, paint, and paper.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to make PRINTS with leaves! Printing means using something to make a copy on paper.'
Paint the vein side of a leaf: 'Cover it with paint, but not too thick. Make sure you get all the way to the edges.'
Press the painted leaf onto the paper, paint side down. Press firmly all over. 'Now lift CAREFULLY...'
'A leaf print! You can see the veins and the shape! Try another leaf with a different color.'

slides.prompt: Make prints with all your leaves. Try overlapping prints and using different colors to make a design!

slides.text: Let prints dry. Clean up paint and brushes. 'You are a printmaker! Artists have used printing for thousands of years.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a recognizable leaf print with clear detail?

parent_notes: Leaf printing introduces the concept of printmaking — one of the oldest art forms. The child learns that an image can be transferred from one surface to another. This connects to the botany curriculum (leaf shapes and veins). Use leaves with strong veins for best results. The child can experiment with pressure — too much paint gives a blob, too little gives a faint print. Finding the right amount is part of the learning.
